column1: San Donato Milanese (Milanese: San Donaa [ˌsãː duˈnɑː]) is a comune (municipality) in the Metropolitan City of Milan in the Italian region Lombardy
column2: located about 10 kilometres (6 mi) southeast of Milan. It is served by the San Donato underground station right on the borderline between the town and Milan and by the San Donato Milanese railway station
column3: serving only trains for the Trenord S1 line "Saronno–Lodi" and vice versa.

column1: Although the area was settled in ancient times
column2: the origins of San Donato date back to the 7th century
column3: when a pieve was founded here by the army of Grimoald I
column4: Duke of Benevento. After a period under the Milanese family De Advocati
column5: the town was a possession of the archbishops of Milan until the 16th century.

column1: A series of abbeys were founded in the area by Bernard of Clairvaux during the 11th century. Later Frederick Barbarossa resided here after his destruction of Milan
column2: while the Visconti and the Torriani fought here (1278) for the possession of the duchy of Milan. The battle of Marignano was also fought nearby
column3: Francis I of France settled his headquarters here after the battle.

column1: Today San Donato is a modern industrial and services centre. It received the honorary title of city with a presidential decree on the 30th of December 1976.
